Award.AwardTitle: Robust Room Temperature Electric Field Control of Structural, Magnetic and Transport Properties of Ultra-Thin Shape Memory Heusler Alloys Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The goal of this project is to demonstrate a new family of nanoferroic multifunctional devices, based on shape-memory Heusler alloy films in ferroelectric heterojunctions, where resistance, magnetic and structural properties of the Heusler alloys will be switchable by applied electric field. Heusler alloys are a group of intermetallic compounds that have unique and interesting electro-magnetic behaviors, including the magnetic shape-memory effect. Selected shape-memory Heusler alloys are expected to be better than manganite-based compounds because their transformations can be controlled to occur near room temperature. This research attempts to distinguish the roles of electronic and strain-mediated coupling between layers in heterojunctions in order to determine the origin of each effect. It also attempts to identify the mechanism of the martensitic phase transformation in the Heusler alloy films. It is ultimately envisioned that this research may lead to a new class of nanoferroic multifunctional devices enabling new sensor and electronic applications. These devices will have a potential for use in memory, sensors and magnetic refrigeration. Long-established participation of high-school teachers and their students in the research laboratories of the investigators will be enhanced. Graduate and undergraduate students will be educated and trained through research activities.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:
The magnetic shape-memory effect in Heusler alloy films will be used to explore physical behaviors of these alloys alone and when paired with other materials to make a functional device. It is ultimately envisioned that this research may lead to a new class of nanoferroic multifunctional devices enabling new sensor and electronic applications. These devices will have a potential for use in memory, sensors and magnetic refrigeration. Long-established participation of high-school teachers and their students in the research laboratories of the investigators will be enhanced. Graduate and undergraduate students will learn nanofabrication techniques, chemical synthesis, sensitive electrical measurements, and theory of quantum transport and magnetization dynamics, providing hands-on experience suitable for their further research and development in leading industrial and academic laboratories.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of our research project is to demonstrate a new family of multi-functional devices, based on Heusler shape memory alloy-ferroelectric heterojunctions, where resistance, magnetic and structural parameters will be switchable by an applied electric field.

During the award period we deepen our fundamental understanding of the origin of magnetic and martensitic phase transitions in Heusler NiMnIn based bulk and thin film systems. We investigated growth mechanism and dynamics of thin and ultra-thin films of NiMnIn based alloys. We evaluated the effect of substrate induced epitaxial strain on martensitic phase transitions in these films. Using DFT based method we examined their magnetic properties such as magnetization, magnetocrystalline anisotropy, magnetooptical Kerr effect and exchange interactions. We examined the details of first order martensitic phase transition in NiMnGa systems. Obtained magnetic, magneto-transport and magneto-optical data were compared with our theoretical predictions and found them in a good agreement.

Additionally, we proposed a large-polarization ferroelectric system with near perfect match in lattice constant with NiMnIn alloys and these lattice constants can be controlled by changing the relative content of the subsystems: PbZrO3/BaZrO3 superlattices. We theoretically proposed a mechanism of electric field control of martensite transformation of Ni-Mn-In thin films deposited on ferroelectric (FE) substrate.

We have alsoexperimentally investigated effects of engineered interface between FE (BaTiO3) and metallic layer (ME). We found that proximity of metallic surface have a detrimental effect on electric polarization of ferroelectric substrate due to the possible hardening of the soft phonon mode in BTO. This effect needs further investigation as it plays a crucial role in electric field control of magnetic and structural phase transition in FE/ME ultra thin films.

Results of our studies have been published in 11 peer-review papers and were presented on many National and International Meetings. These results deepen and extend the fundamental understanding of synthesis and magnetostructural behavior of Heusler alloys and the effect of FE proximity on their properties. These results are crucial for many memory related technologies and next generation logical elements.

Besides these scientific achievements, the NSF funding helped significantly in development of human resources and education. Two post-docs, one graduate students and three undergraduate student were actively involved in this research. All of them currently continue their study and research in Physics at UNL and other US based universities. We were fortunate enough to have a close collaboration with science teacher from a local high school and 3 of his talented student were continuously working on this project. All 3 student are now pursuing their degree in a STEM field at UNL and other leading US universities. PI and co-PI of the project presented many talks on National and International meetings educating young scientists and interested professionals in the area of materials science and phase transitions stimulated by an electric fields.
